title: 106_hr2876
content:
The "Kenneth Starr Corrections Act of 1999" may be cited as the short title. Testimonial privileges in federal, civil, and criminal proceedings are addressed in the Act. Rule 501 of the Federal Rules of Evidence is amended to include protections for witnesses regarding testimony against children or parents and disclosure of confidential communications. The amended Rule 501 of the Federal Rules of Evidence includes protections for witnesses, such as the right to act as a parent and privileges similar to those of a witness with respect to a spouse. Additionally, a member of the United States Secret Service cannot be compelled to testify about any conversation of the President heard while on duty. SEC. 3. RESTRICTIONS ON PROSECUTORIAL CONDUCT. Amends Part II of title 18, United States Code by adding CHAPTER 237--RESTRICTIONS, including Sec. 3761 on restrictions on prosecutorial conduct. Sec. 3761 imposes restrictions on prosecutorial conduct regarding perjury prosecutions based on grand jury testimony. Prosecutors cannot bring charges against a witness for perjury if the statement was made in response to a question asked by the prosecutor or grand jury member and based on physical evidence not provided to the witness before their testimony. Sec. 3761 imposes restrictions on perjury prosecutions related to grand jury testimony. Prosecutors cannot charge a witness for perjury if the statement was made in response to a question asked by the prosecutor or grand jury member and based on physical evidence not provided to the witness before their testimony. Additionally, limitations are placed on prosecuting individuals for false statements in affidavits related to adultery or non-unlawful sexual activity in civil cases. Officers or employees of the United States are prohibited from authorizing audio or video recordings of private communications expected to relate to adultery or non-unlawful sexual activity. Title 18, United States Code, is amended to include a new chapter after chapter 235. SEC. 4. LIMITATIONS APPLICABLE TO PROCEEDINGS BEFORE THE GRAND JURY: Rule 6 of the Federal Rules of Criminal Procedure is amended to prohibit photographic records of witnesses testifying before a grand jury.

SEC. 5. IMMUNITY FOR CERTAIN GRAND JURY WITNESSES: Individuals targeted in a US law violation investigation cannot be compelled to appear before a grand jury without a specific order.

SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATE; APPLICATION OF AMENDMENTS: These amendments will take effect as specified in the title. SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATE; APPLICATION OF AMENDMENTS: This Act and its amendments will take effect on the enactment date, applying only to conduct after that date.
